etymology.description: hand (又) holding a brush (𰀁); originally referred to 筆 ‘writing brush’; later jiajie (rebus) for 聿 ‘thereupon’.
etymology.interpretation: A right hand gripping a writing brush vividly depicts the act of writing. Its graph first named the brush itself and was later borrowed to represent the adverbial sense “thereupon/then” in classical usage.

examples.chinese: 古人以聿书竹帛(古人以聿書竹帛)。
examples.english: The ancients used a brush to write on bamboo and silk.

examples.chinese: 他执聿临池练字(他執聿臨池練字)。
examples.english: He holds the brush by the water to practice calligraphy.

examples.chinese: 史官持聿记事(史官持聿記事)。
examples.english: The scribe holds a brush to record events.
